meta.title: Unbiased Estimation and U-statistics
intro.title: Unbiased Estimation and U-statistics
intro.lead: We introduce unbiased estimators, counterexamples, and generalize them through U- and V-statistics.
sec.def.title: Definition of Unbiased Estimator
sec.def.caption: Unbiased Estimator
sec.def.p1: Let $X = (X_1, \ldots, X_n)$ be a sample from $\{ p(x \mid \theta); \theta \in \Theta \}.$
sec.def.p2: An estimator $T(X)$ of $q(\theta)$ is called unbiased if the equality holds. A parameter $q(\theta)$ is unbiasedly estimable if such an estimator exists.

sec.counter.title: Other Examples and Counterexample
sec.counter.caption: Examples and Counterexample
sec.counter.text1: Consider $X_1,\ldots,X_n \sim \mathrm{Bernoulli}(p)$. Then $T_1(X) = X_1$ and $T_2(X) = \bar{X}$ are unbiased for $p$.
sec.counter.text2: However, $T_3(X) = X_1 + 10$ is biased since $\mathbb{E}[T_3(X)] = p + 10 \neq p$, while $T_4(X) = X_1 + \frac{1}{n}$ is asymptotically unbiased as $n \to \infty$.
sec.ustat.title: U-statistics
sec.ustat.caption: U-statistic
sec.ustat.text1: A statistic of this form is called a U-statistic with kernel $h$ of order $m$.
sec.ustat.text2: In the Bernoulli case, $h(x)=x$ and $U_n=\bar{X}$ is itself unbiased for $p$.
sec.algo.title: Algorithm — Constructing a U-statistic
sec.algo.header: Algorithm: General Procedure for Building a U-statistic
sec.algo.input.label: Input:
sec.algo.input: Independent sample $X = (X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n)$ and kernel $h(x_1, \ldots, x_m)$ of order $m$.
sec.algo.output.label: Output:
sec.algo.step1: Determine the kernel $h(x_1, \ldots, x_m)$ representing the unbiased form.
sec.algo.step2: Enumerate all $m$-combinations of indices from $1$ to $n$.
sec.algo.loop.caption: Computation Loop
sec.algo.step3: Average all kernel values to obtain $U_n$.
sec.vstat.title: Reference — V-statistics
sec.vstat.caption: V-statistic
sec.vstat.text1: A V-statistic allows repeated indices in the summation and is also known as the von Mises statistic.
